lines.text: Enter QUINCE, SNUG, BOTTOM, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING

lines.speaker: quince
lines.text: Is all our company here?

lines.speaker: bottom
lines.text: You were best to call them generally, man by man, according to the scrip.

lines.speaker: quince
lines.text: Here is the scroll of every man's name, which is thought fit, through all Athens, to play in our interlude before the duke and the duchess, on his wedding-day at night.

lines.speaker: bottom
lines.text: First, good Peter Quince, say what the play treats on, then read the names of the actors, and so grow to a point.

lines.speaker: quince
lines.text: Marry, our play is, The most lamentable comedy, and most cruel death of Pyramus and Thisby.

lines.speaker: bottom
lines.text: A very good piece of work, I assure you, and a merry. Now, good Peter Quince, call forth your actors by the scroll. Masters, spread yourselves.

lines.speaker: quince
lines.text: Answer as I call you. Nick Bottom, the weaver.

lines.speaker: bottom
lines.text: Ready. Name what part I am for, and proceed.

lines.speaker: quince
lines.text: You, Nick Bottom, are set down for Pyramus.

lines.speaker: bottom
lines.text: What is Pyramus? a lover, or a tyrant?

lines.speaker: quince
lines.text: A lover, that kills himself most gallant for love.

lines.speaker: bottom
lines.text: That will ask some tears in the true performing of it: if I do it, let the audience look to their eyes; I will move storms, I will condole in some measure. To the rest: yet my chief humour is for a tyrant: I could play Ercles rarely, or a part to tear a cat in, to make all split. The raging rocks And shivering shocks Shall break the locks Of prison gates; And Phibbus' car Shall shine from far And make and mar The foolish Fates. This was lofty! Now name the rest of the players. This is Ercles' vein, a tyrant's vein; a lover is more condoling.

lines.speaker: quince
lines.text: Francis Flute, the bellows-mender.

lines.speaker: flute
lines.text: Here, Peter Quince.

lines.speaker: quince
lines.text: Flute, you must take Thisby on you.

lines.speaker: flute
lines.text: What is Thisby? a wandering knight?

lines.speaker: quince
lines.text: It is the lady that Pyramus must love.

lines.speaker: flute
lines.text: Nay, faith, let me not play a woman; I have a beard coming.

lines.speaker: quince
lines.text: That's all one: you shall play it in a mask, and you may speak as small as you will.

lines.speaker: bottom
lines.text: An I may hide my face, let me play Thisby too, I'll speak in a monstrous little voice. 'Thisne, Thisne;' 'Ah, Pyramus, lover dear! thy Thisby dear, and lady dear!'

lines.speaker: quince
lines.text: No, no; you must play Pyramus: and, Flute, you Thisby.

lines.speaker: bottom
lines.text: Well, proceed.

lines.speaker: quince
lines.text: Robin Starveling, the tailor.

lines.speaker: starveling
lines.text: Here, Peter Quince.

lines.speaker: quince
lines.text: Robin Starveling, you must play Thisby's mother. Tom Snout, the tinker.

lines.speaker: snout
lines.text: Here, Peter Quince.

lines.speaker: quince
lines.text: You, Pyramus' father: myself, Thisby's father: Snug, the joiner; you, the lion's part: and, I hope, here is a play fitted.

lines.speaker: snug
lines.text: Have you the lion's part written? pray you, if it be, give it me, for I am slow of study.

lines.speaker: quince
lines.text: You may do it extempore, for it is nothing but roaring.

lines.speaker: bottom
lines.text: Let me play the lion too: I will roar, that I will do any man's heart good to hear me; I will roar, that I will make the duke say 'Let him roar again, let him roar again.'

lines.speaker: quince
lines.text: An you should do it too terribly, you would fright the duchess and the ladies, that they would shriek; and that were enough to hang us all.

lines.speaker: all
lines.text: That would hang us, every mother's son.

lines.speaker: bottom
lines.text: I grant you, friends, if that you should fright the ladies out of their wits, they would have no more discretion but to hang us: but I will aggravate my voice so that I will roar you as gently as any sucking dove; I will roar you an 'twere any nightingale.

lines.speaker: quince
lines.text: You can play no part but Pyramus; for Pyramus is a sweet-faced man; a proper man, as one shall see in a summer's day; a most lovely gentleman-like man: therefore you must needs play Pyramus.

lines.speaker: bottom
lines.text: Well, I will undertake it. What beard were I best to play it in?

lines.speaker: quince
lines.text: Why, what you will.

lines.speaker: bottom
lines.text: I will discharge it in either your straw-colour beard, your orange-tawny beard, your purple-in-grain beard, or your French-crown-colour beard, your perfect yellow.

lines.speaker: quince
lines.text: Some of your French crowns have no hair at all, and then you will play bare-faced. But, masters, here are your parts: and I am to entreat you, request you and desire you, to con them by to-morrow night; and meet me in the palace wood, a mile without the town, by moonlight; there will we rehearse, for if we meet in the city, we shall be dogged with company, and our devices known. In the meantime I will draw a bill of properties, such as our play wants. I pray you, fail me not.

lines.speaker: bottom
lines.text: We will meet; and there we may rehearse most obscenely and courageously. Take pains; be perfect: adieu.

lines.speaker: quince
lines.text: At the duke's oak we meet.

lines.speaker: bottom
lines.text: Enough; hold or cut bow-strings.
Exeunt
